summary.body: We've just come back from a lovely first visit to the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar. Gorgeous food, great service, wonderful setting.  When it came to paying the bill, we asked if we could pay the main part with a card but pay the service charge in cash to ensure the staff get it. We have no problem excercising this legal right in other restaurants. You may or may not be aware but whenever the service charge is paid with a card, the staff do not get it but the corporation who owns the restaurant does. Time Out Magazine wrote a piece about a year ago stating that if you want to ensure the staff who served you are rewarded with a tip, then pay the service charge in cash. Our friendly and efficient waitress asked the manager on our behalf if we could do this, but she refused. We HAD to pay it with the card.  We were shocked that the manager refused point blankly and didn't even come over to explain why but decided not to go any further, we had a lovely meal in wonderful surroundings but ended up paying the waitress some more on top of the service charge as we left, just because we felt so bad for her.  She seemed to have no idea that she was entitled to the service charge. At St Paul's Chez Gerard, our regular haunt we often pay the service charge in cash and it goes directly to the staff. NB: the manager of the Wood Street Bar is the daughter of one of the three owners, who also own other restaurants, which is probably why she didn't want the staff to get the tips but her father's company instead. When we go next week, we'll have to point blankly refuse to pay the service charge with a card or bring extra cash. I understand Wood Street Restaurant is very popular with us Barbican residents on Sundays. May I suggest, if you'd like the service charge to go to the staff (and not just the manager's family and business partners), that you consider paying it in cash and ask for this right if they refuse you. We will, as otherwise, there's no incentive for good service.  In other London restaurants (and other parts of the world, especially the States) , waiters and waitresses thrive on their good tips, it's a shame that their right to this has been eroded at our local.  Has anyone else experienced the same problem at the Wood Street or any other local restaurants?
summary.subject: Tips at the Wood Street Restaurant and Bar

summary.body: Some of our Barbican area pubs and restaurants appear to have serious problems with mice. The other night, I watched a feral mouse make a bold dash across a local pub floor for dropped crisps. I'd already decided not to visit this particular pub again, because even with only 6 customers in a large space, it was too full of smoke to stay in there longer than one drink anyway (roll on 1st July). Friends have reported dining out in a local restaurant and watching a mouse scurry around the restaurant floor. Later that night, one of them got food poisoning, but having consumed alcohol, it was difficult to safely conclude any link with the resturant's mouse or their food. (Personally, I wouldn't have paid for my meal. I'd have quietly pointed out the issue to staff and promptly left the premises.) Obviously mice are not uncommon in London, but being present in such a bold way in public places suggests a serious infestation. Has anyone else seen mice in our local pubs and restaurants?
summary.subject: Mice

summary.body: For those who enjoy eating out a spate of new restaurants seem to have opened or about to open close by.  This evening I had a long chat to the owner of a new Turkish restaurant and cafe in Charterhouse Street (right next to the Rendezvous) called Issus and he's a real restaurant enthusiast who sold up a place in Tottenham to open one here.  The food I sampled was extremely tasty and was washed down with a Turkish dry white wine which was surprisingly good.  Another ethnic restaurant to add to the diversity of food in the area.  It seems reasonable value and is worth a try and the owner, David, is signing up to the BA Members' Discount scheme and will offer 10% off to BA members.  David may even read your fortune in Turkish Coffee grounds if you ask him nicely!  Service is very friendly.  It's open Monday to Saturday from 12 noon to 11pm.  It also has a Cafe section downstairs open from 2 a.m. to 4 pm.  A lunch special at 8.00 for two starters and one main course is also on offer which seems like good value. On my way back I tried a slight detour and had a talk to the Proprietor/Chef of Le Saint Julien which has replaced one of the two Mustards restaurants in Long Lane.  His name is Francois Jobard and he hails from Avignon in Provence and is bringing an authentic French atmosphere and menu to the restaurant.  Haven't yet persuaded him to join the BA discount scheme, but am working on it.  However my understanding is that they will offer you a free kir on sitting down to a meal.  the atmosphere looks attractive and there is even a set (but rather limited) two course menu at 10.95 I also noticed that the old Bar Bombay - previously the Gulshan - is now rbeing replaced by a new establishnment under new management which reckons to be opening soon. For those of us who enjoy eating out from time to time there is lots of choice of all kinds of food.  Its a good idea to try out new places and if your experiences are good, do recommend them to others here.
summary.subject: New Restaurants

summary.body: pinchito has opened in Featherstone St, just behind Old street  ... tapas galore and all delicious, with a wine list that does lots by the glass too ... lots of old favourites ... potatas bravas, chorizo etc etc but all very well done ... fave dish (sadly, given its also the unhealthiest) was anchovies on crisps ... now i know its ounds odd, but splendid it was ...  best sight was a table of six, four of whom were smokers... they of course had to go outside at which point their "friends" truly guzzled what was left of the food ...   give it a whirl

All the same, had a real good curry at a price I'm happy to pay!

summary.body: on the way back from the Tate the other evening, with a freezing wind blowing and feeling decidely chilled, we stopped off at Terra Nostra , which is at  27 Old Bailey EC4M 7HS  City 020 3201 0077  it was really good - the sardinian bent really lifting it above the usual fairly flaccid italian restaurant moment ... lovely kind of fish platter thing to start, then sardinian pasta with sausage-y sauce, which was perfect for a cold night, even though i could feel my waist expanding markedly...  we were the only ones in there for a fair while, which was a bit weird, but the staff are great and friendly without making you feel you've got to ask them about the health of their great aunt ... anyway, worth a look
summary.subject: really good sardinian restaurant

summary.body: Anyone who enjoys authentic Japanese food might be interested to know that Matsuri Restaurant, High Holborn has a special deal on Saturday lunch during August - you pay only 50% of normal prices. Normally keenly priced, this is excellent value and highly recommended based on a recent visit. The restaurant is being fairly coy about this promotion but it seems already to be well known to the local Japanese community so make sure they can accommodate you. If you are still hungry, cross the road on the way back and take home one of the excellent cakes from Paul, the highly recommended French baker. For the avoidance of doubt, I have no financial interest whatsoever in either of these establishments.
